properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10-15 cm of wet snow is expected in Lake Louise today. Near Banff, most of the precipitation will start as rain this morning, but change to snow this afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T05:07:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T17:30:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4107815318.2020
Area: Clearwater Co. near Siffleur Wilderness Area, Banff Nat. Park near Saskatchewan River Crossing, Banff Nat. Park near Lake Louise, Banff Nat. Park near Banff
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Visibilities will be reduced to near zero in blowing snow beginning Sunday afternoon and until Monday afternoon. An intense low pressure system will reach Newfoundland Sunday, bringing snow, very strong winds and blowing snow over the Eastern Lower North Shore through Monday. Total snowfall amounts approaching 15 centimetres are expected, and northerly winds gusting at times up to 80 kilometres per hour will give widespread blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T12:35:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T20:36:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3091008827.2020
Area: Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are occurring along the Icefields Parkway. A long duration heavy snowfall event is occurring and is expected to end this evening. Another 10-20 cm of snow is expected today. Total snowfall amounts will be between 30 and 50 cm, with locally upwards of 70 cm possible. Strong winds will accompany the snow, which will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow at times, especially over exposed areas. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T04:59:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T17:31:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1680998380.2020
Area: Highway 93 South - Lake Louise to Saskatchewan River Crossing, Highway 93 North - Jasper to Saskatchewan River Crossing
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds of 70 gusting 100 km/h continue. The winds will begin to taper off this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T06:34:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T22:28:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1982518219.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h from the northeast and northwest. Locations: Norman Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: Sunday afternoon until Monday evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to begin Sunday afternoon before tapering off to flurries Monday morning in the Red Bay to L'anse-au-Clair area. Snow and blowing snow will continue until Monday evening in the Norman Bay to Lodge Bay area. The fresh snow combined with strong winds will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow Sunday evening through Monday evening. Winds are expected to further strengthen Monday afternoon in the Norman Bay to Lodge Bay area when the winds shift around to northwesterly with gusts up to 100 km/h possible. Visibility is expected to be near zero along exposed areas of the coast during this time. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-02T18:14:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-02T02:15:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1850705914.2020
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Locally heavy snowfall will continue this evening and tonight. Snow is expected to end by Sunday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T14:29:06-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. An area of freezing rain over north central Saskatchewan continues to track southeastward across the northern grainbelt. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm Sunday. Additional amounts of 10 to 15 cm likely along the west coast and Great Northern Peninsula Monday. Locations: southwestern, western. northern and central Newfoundland including the Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: Sunday morning until Monday evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to begin Sunday morning. Snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm are expected in most areas before the snow tapers to flurries Sunday evening. Winds are expected to increase throughout the day with northeasterly gusts near 70 km/h by Sunday afternoon. The fresh snow combined with strong winds will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow on Sunday afternoon. Snow will continue along the west coast and over the Great Northern Peninsula on Monday, eventually tapering to flurries on Monday evening. Visibility may continue to be poor on Monday in these areas due to a continuing moderate westerly wind. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-02T18:12:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-02T02:13:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2341897068.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Green Bay - White Bay, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: Sunday afternoon until near midnight Sunday night. Remarks: Snow is forecast to change to rain at times heavy near noon on the southern Avalon, and a few hours later in the north. The combination of fresh fallen snow, already existing snowpack and falling rain will cause hazardous driving conditions and localized flooding in areas where water is not able to drain properly. Areas of the southeastern Avalon have the highest chance of exceeding forecast rainfall totals. Precipitation will quickly taper off near midnight on Sunday night. However, temperatures will fall below freezing by morning. Expect icy conditions by Monday morning. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-02T18:07:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-02T02:08:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3849550135.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. Concentrations of fine particulate matter are high in the Greater Montreal Area and will remain so Saturday night and Sunday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canadaâs website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in QuÃ©bec, visit the MinistÃ¨re de la SantÃ© et des Services sociauxâs website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction rÃ©gionale de santÃ© publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-lâÃle-de-MontrÃ©al at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Weekend snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, but potentially approaching 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 60 km/h possible. Locations: central and eastern Nova Scotia. Time span: late this afternoon to early Sunday morning. Remarks: A developing storm approaching from the southwest is forecast to pass just east of Cape Breton on Sunday morning. Snow associated with the system will spread to all of central and eastern Nova Scotia by this evening and then taper to flurries Sunday morning. Snowfall warnings remain in effect for Antigonish County, Guysborough County, and all of Cape Breton. The latest forecast guidance continues to indicate lesser snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm just to the west of these areas. However, there is still some uncertainty in the track of this system, and a shift to the northwest could increase snowfall amounts over central Nova Scotia. The forecast will be updated as the system approaches. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T11:40:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T19:41:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2670353767.2020
Area: Colchester County North, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeast 80 km/h, possibly up to northwest 100 km/h in the Black Tickle area Monday. Locations: Cartwright to Black Tickle. Time span: overnight Sunday until Monday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop overnight Sunday and will become heavy at times Monday morning. Fresh snowfall and strong winds will combine to give reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially in the Black Tickle area where visibilities may be near zero Monday. Conditions are expected to improve Monday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-02T18:15:41-00:00

Area: Cartwright to Black Tickle
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 100 km/h along the coast. Locations: southern Avalon and Burin peninsulas. Time span: Sunday afternoon. Remarks: Southeasterly winds are expected to increase Sunday morning with gusts reaching up to 100 km/h along the coast by Sunday afternoon. Winds will quickly subside and shift to southwesterly by Sunday evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. Concentrations of fine particulate matter will remain high tonight into Sunday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canadaâs website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow expected. Total snowfall: near 15 cm with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: southern, eastern, northeastern and parts of central Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday morning until Sunday evening. Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, is forecast to begin Sunday morning. Snowfall accumulations of near 15 cm are expected by early Sunday evening before the snow begins to mix with or change briefly to rain. Rain is expected to be most significant in the south, where the Burin Peninsula could see 10 to 20 mm by the time precipitation tapers Sunday evening. Some localized flooding is possible in that area due to existing snow pack. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-02T18:07:51-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: near 15 cm for the eastern mainland and 15 to 25 cm for Cape Breton. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 70 km/h. Locations: eastern mainland and Cape Breton. Time span: tonight and Sunday. Remarks: Snow will continue tonight across eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton. The greatest snowfall accumulations are expected over Guysborough, Richmond, Sydney, and Victoria counties. Rain will likely mix with the snow along the Atlantic coast before the precipitation ends from west to east during the day on Sunday. In addition, there is a risk of freezing rain inland tonight and early Sunday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T18:22:15-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong westerly winds persist over over extreme southwestern Saskatchewan. Strong winds, with winds gusting to 90 km/h or higher, are expected with winds gradually diminishing below warning criteria this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T17:23:29-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong southwesterly winds are expected to develop later this morning and persist into the afternoon. The strongest winds, with winds gusting to 90 km/h or higher, are expected along the Trans Canada highway from the Alberta - Saskatchewan boundary to Maple Creek. Winds are expected to diminish below warning criteria by early evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
